name: gam Lib
scenarioDescription:
The gam Lib Exoplanetary System

gam Lib is a star with 1.47 times the mass of the Sun, and 11.1 times its radius. It is located 154.70 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2.82 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

gam Lib is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

gam Lib b

gam Lib b was discovered by the Okayama Astrophysical Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 415.20 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, gam Lib.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.21, which means that when gam Lib b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.98 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 1.50. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of gam Lib b is 324.17 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, gam Lib b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

gam Lib c

gam Lib c was discovered by the Okayama Astrophysical Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 2.17 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 964.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, gam Lib.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.057, which means that when gam Lib c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 2.05 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 2.29. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of gam Lib c is 1455.57 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, gam Lib c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system gam Lib, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Okayama Astrophysical Observatory.
